answers.text: positive knowledge of God is possible

qas.question: Who influenced Magnus at this time?
What is it easier to do regarding God?
How do we deny things of God?
Who did not champion the idea drawn from Dionysus?
Who believed that negative knowledge of God is possible, but obsure?
What is not easier to do regarding God?
How do we accept things of God?

plausible_answers.text: a relative affirmation and an absolute negation

context: <b4_0><b5_0>Albertus Magnus<b5_0/><b4_0/> championed the idea, drawn from <a1_0>Dionysus<a1_0/>, that <a0_0>positive knowledge of God is possible<a0_0/>, but obscure. Thus, it is easier to <a2_0><b6_0>state what God is not<b6_0/><a2_0/>, than to state what God is: "... we affirm things of God only relatively, that is, casually, whereas we deny things of God <a3_0><b7_0>absolutely<b7_0/><a3_0/>, that is, with reference to what He is in Himself. And there is no contradiction between <b8_0>a relative affirmation and an absolute negation<b8_0/>. It is not contradictory to say that someone is white-toothed and not white".
